name: 4-(4-Chloro-benzylidene)-2-phenyl-4H-oxazol-5-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3797
Reason: The compound has a benzene core with additional functional groups that influence its melting point. The chlorobenzylidene group adds steric hindrance and polarizability due to the chlorine atom, which can increase the melting point by about +50°C over the base benzene value. The oxazolone ring contains oxygen and nitrogen heteroatoms that are capable of engaging in hydrogen bonding, adding substantial rigidity and polar character; this could contribute +100°C. Additionally, the extra phenyl ring increases the planarity and π-π stacking capability, which might add roughly +40°C due to increased van der Waals forces. Collectively, these functional group effects sum up to +190°C, over the base value of benzene.
Test (Predicted reason):
The compound 4-(4-Chloro-benzylidene)-2-phenyl-4H-oxazol-5-one has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base structure is an oxazole ring, which has a melting point of around 100°C. The presence of a benzene ring adds rigidity and increases the melting point due to π-π interactions, which can be estimated to add approximately +20°C. The chloro substituent on the benzene ring is electron-withdrawing and can increase the melting point due to increased polarity and potential for intermolecular interactions, estimated at +10°C. The ketone group (C=O) is capable of hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, which can significantly raise the melting point, estimated at +40°C. The conjugation between the benzene and the oxazole ring also contributes to the rigidity and planarity of the molecule, which can further increase the melting point, estimated at +10°C. The cumulative effect of these functional groups leads to an increase in the melting point.
